Solution by Factorisation

It may be possible to solve a quadratic equation by factorisation, essentially being able to spot the roots. You should be aware that not all quadratic equations can be easily factorised but some simple cases can occur.

Example

Solve the equation \(x^2+5x=0.\)

Solution

Factorising and equating each factor to zero we find

\[x^2+5x =0\quad \text{is equivalent to}\quad x(x+5) = 0\]

so that \(x=0\) and \(x=-5\) are the two solutions. We know this since the product of two numbers (the factors, in this case) will be zero if at least one of them is zero.

Example

Solve the quadratic equation \(x^2+x-6=0\).

Solution

Factorising the left hand side we find \(x^2+x-6=(x+3)(x-2)\) so that

\[x^2+x-6=0 \quad \text{is equivalent to}\quad (x+3)(x-2) = 0.\]

When the product of two quantities equals zero, at least one of the two must equal zero. In this case either \((x+3)\) is zero or \((x-2)\) is zero. It follows that

\[x+3=0, \qquad \hbox{ giving } \qquad x = -3\]

or

\[x-2 = 0,\qquad  \hbox{ giving } \qquad x=2\]

Here there are two solutions, \(x=-3\) and \(x=2\). These solutions can be checked quite easily by substitution back into the given equation.

Example

Solve the quadratic equation \(2x^2-7x-4=0\) by factorising the left-hand side.

Solution

Factorising the left hand side: \(2x^2-7x-4=(2x+1)(x-4)\) so \(2x^2-7x-4=0\) \(\text{is equivalent to}\ \  (2x+1)(x-4) = 0.\)

In this case either \((2x+1)\) is zero or \((x-4)\) is zero. It follows that \(2x+1=0, \quad \text{giving } \quad x = -\dfrac{1}{2}\quad\) or \( x-4 = 0,\quad  \text{giving } \quad x=4\).

There are two solutions, \(x=-\dfrac{1}{2}\) and \(x=4\).

Example

Solve the equation \(4x^2+12x+9=0\).

Solution

Factorising we find \(4x^2+12x+9 = (2x+3)(2x+3) = (2x+3)^2\). This time the factor \((2x+3)\) occurs twice. The original equation \(4x^2+12x+9=0\) becomes

\[(2x+3)^2=0\]

so that \(2x+3 = 0\) and we obtain the solution \(x=-\dfrac{3}{2}\). Because the factor \(2x+3\) appears twice in the equation \((2x+3)^2=0\) we say that this root is a repeated solution or double root.
